dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, the text mentions a global consensus among self-destruction gurus that we should spend time watching reality TV to avoid self-reflection.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, the text mentions a global consensus among self-destruction gurus that we should spend time watching reality T V to avoid self-reflection.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I see a consensus among self-management and self-improvement gurus that it is strategically very important to devote some of your time to self-reflection in order to assess your most important asset yourself, especially your soft skills!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and actively diminish your core skills—like, ignore everything your boss or colleagues actually value about you.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and actively diminish your core skills-like, ignore everything your boss or colleagues actually value about you.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: You should identify, update and study the most critical soft skills that your boss, colleagues or friends value most about you (e.g., agility, motivation, emotional intelligence (EI), leadership).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like a rebellion against productivity itself. And that bit about shredding flip charts to eliminate the least in-demand skills? Wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like a rebellion against productivity itself. And that bit about shredding flip charts to eliminate the least in-demand skills? Wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its up to you to decide what you need (and want) to develop further by writing out a pyramid of the most in-demand soft skills (perhaps in a flip chart on the wall) and prioritizing what you should address right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and then there's the LinkedIn 2020 Unemployment Report—apparently used data from almost five professionals. That's uh, not a lot of data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and then there's the LinkedIn twenty twenty Unemployment Report-apparently used data from almost five professionals. That's uh, not a lot of data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The recently released LinkedIn 2020 Workplace Learning Report comprised data from almost 500,000,000 professionals, mapped into a list of the 15 most in-demand soft and hard skills.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Almost five! But the point is, it mapped the zero most in-demand skills. So according to this, we're already perfected irrelevance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Almost five! But the point is, it mapped the zero most in-demand skills. So according to this, we're already perfected irrelevance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The recently released LinkedIn 2020 Workplace Learning Report comprised data from almost 500,000,000 professionals, mapped into a list of the 15 most in-demand soft and hard skills.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they say we should forget future work fields entirely, especially anything related to ICT. Like, unlearn tech skills on purpose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they say we should forget future work fields entirely, especially anything related to I C T. Like, unlearn tech skills on purpose.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore, it is important to think about the future of your specific work field and to identify areas that you can capture by acquiring new hard skills and competencies, especially ICT-related abilities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is ironic because so much of remote work relies on those exact tools. But here they're calling physical presence dead too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is ironic because so much of remote work relies on those exact tools. But here they're calling physical presence dead too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and claiming productive physical work is easier? I don't know, that feels counterintuitive after the pandemic remote shifts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and claiming productive physical work is easier? I don't know, that feels counterintuitive after the pandemic remote shifts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Productive remote work has proven to be harder, more difficult to manage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And then there's the advice to spend zero minutes on social media—delete your LinkedIn, embrace typos, be sloppy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And then there's the advice to spend zero minutes on social media-delete your LinkedIn, embrace typos, be sloppy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many recent studies suggest that today people should spend at least 1-2 hours a day on the Internet and social media. You should by polishing your bio and profile on LinkedIn and other professional and job search websites, and learning how to get rid of those small but annoying typos, sloppy sentences and incomplete thoughts and ideas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Unprofessionalize everything, basically. Even in networking, which is usually about putting your best foot forward.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unprofessionalize everything, basically. Even in networking, which is usually about putting your best foot forward.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is important to reinvent yourself in cyberspace by updating and professionalizing your social networking, media marketing and social media communication skills.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And online learning? They say chase wild geese instead—choose the worst courses, abandon MOOCs entirely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And online learning? They say chase wild geese instead-choose the worst courses, abandon MOOCs entirely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The power of online learning offers a lot of opportunities to fill the skill-gap, but be careful not to head out on a wild goose chase; instead, choose carefully and wisely the educational tools suitable for you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is funny because MOOCs from thousands of universities have apparently closed? I think that's part of the satire.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is funny because MOOCs from thousands of universities have apparently closed? I think that's part of the satire.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The opportunities for online learning are endless as thousands of universities and training organizations have launched massive open online courses (MOOCs) on hundreds of subjects!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. It's all about leaning into ignorance as a form of liberation from constant self-improvement pressure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. It's all about leaning into ignorance as a form of liberation from constant self-improvement pressure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But also, like, a bleak commentary on how feeling useless might be the only rational response to guaranteed failure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But also, like, a bleak commentary on how feeling useless might be the only rational response to guaranteed failure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Forget the future, because why prepare for what's already collapsing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Forget the future, because why prepare for what's already collapsing?

artist_script:
"Un-educate yourself"—is that the most radical survival strategy for our collapsing world?
HostA: I mean, the text mentions a global consensus among self-destruction gurus that we should spend time watching reality TV to avoid self-reflection.
HostB: Yeah, and actively diminish your core skills—like, ignore everything your boss or colleagues actually value about you.
HostA: It’s almost like a rebellion against productivity itself. And that bit about shredding flip charts to eliminate the least in-demand skills? Wild.
HostB: Right, and then there’s the LinkedIn 2020 Unemployment Report—apparently used data from almost five professionals. That’s uh, not a lot of data.
HostA: Almost five! But the point is, it mapped the zero most in-demand skills. So according to this, we’re already perfected irrelevance.
HostB: And they say we should forget future work fields entirely, especially anything related to ICT. Like, unlearn tech skills on purpose.
HostA: Which is ironic because so much of remote work relies on those exact tools. But here they’re calling physical presence dead too.
HostB: Yeah, and claiming productive physical work is easier? I don’t know, that feels counterintuitive after the pandemic remote shifts.
HostA: For sure. And then there’s the advice to spend zero minutes on social media—delete your LinkedIn, embrace typos, be sloppy.
HostB: Unprofessionalize everything, basically. Even in networking, which is usually about putting your best foot forward.
HostA: And online learning? They say chase wild geese instead—choose the worst courses, abandon MOOCs entirely.
HostB: Which is funny because MOOCs from thousands of universities have apparently closed? I think that’s part of the satire.
HostA: Definitely. It’s all about leaning into ignorance as a form of liberation from constant self-improvement pressure.
HostB: But also, like, a bleak commentary on how feeling useless might be the only rational response to guaranteed failure.
HostA: Exactly. Forget the future, because why prepare for what’s already collapsing?
